turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: Terrific! A born stooge! Horace'll perform like a trained seal.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Jim--if I fling a party man like Horace in the face of those angry committees--

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: He's batty!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Listen--the simpleton of all time--a big-eyed patriot--knows Washington and Lincoln by heart--stood at attention in the Governor's presence-- collects stray boys and cats--

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: Oh--oh.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: He's the hero of fifty thousand boys and a hundred thousand parents. Look at these congratulations pouring in! I tell you, gentlemen, by this one statesman-like act, I have--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Look here, Jim--if you and Joe are going to gab about this appointment *any* longer, I'm going ahead and see those committees!

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: You'll see those committees when we're finished!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Yes, Jim.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: One minute! Just one minute!

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Happy, we've got the man. Horace Miller!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Horace Mill--!

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Happy, for reasons there isn't time to go into--it's got to be Miller! We've given you the man. Now write the ticket.  Come on, Joe. Come on, Chick.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Now, wait fellows--great Heavens. I've got to see those angry committees first--feel them out a little--work for harmony--harmony.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: They put up *their* candidate? Who?

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Henry Hill.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: *Henry Hill?* That crackpot? That long-haired--! Why, you should have killed that so fast--!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: I--I couldn't, Jim. Those men were--

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: We can't help *what* they were! Forget 'em!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Jim, that bunch is out for blood. If I throw Horace in their teeth now--

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: I said forget 'em! Horace Miller goes to the Senate--and that settles it!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: I *won't* send Horace Miller!

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: *You won't?*

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: I *won't* let you stand there callously and perhaps wreck my whole political future!

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: *Your* political future! I bought it for you and made you a present. And I can grab it back so fast it'll make your head spin. You got a nerve to stand there and worry about just *your future* when we're in this spot!  The man is--*Miller*.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: --a *boy ranger* a squirrel chaser-- to the United States Senate!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Jim--the answer to a prayer--manna from heaven--the man *we want*--and the votes *we need*--

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Joe--*you* know what I'm talking about. The perfect man. Never in politics in his life. Wouldn't find out what it's all about in two *years*, lets alone two months. But the important thing--and this was the genius of the stroke--*it means votes*!

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: But you went ahead and made this appointment without asking me--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Jim--when the lightning hit, I--I just--

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: *But you never asked me*!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Oh--Jim!

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Boy Ranger! The answer to a prayer. Manna from heaven! Didn't know the time of day--!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Will you please tell me *exactly* what he's done?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes! He's about to blow the whole machine to smithereens--and *you with it*, Mr. Governor!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Me! Jim--how--?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: You couldn't understand! Listen, Ten Thumbs, I'll be on my way to Washington in half an hour. Whatever happens, I'm all ready for this Ranger of yours. Never mind how. You'll get your instructions from Ken Allen here. It isn't anything you have to do. I wouldn't trust you to lick a stamp. Allen'll do it himself. You just use your *high office* to help him get it done. Understand?

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Y-yes, Jim.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: I doubt it! Come on, Ken.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Now--now--please--that's quite all right. Relax, boys--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: This--this is a great honor, sir. I-- I--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Not at all. I've come to pay you a personal and official--and I might say--a *tardy* tribute, Mr. Smith, for your recent heroic conduct.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh, now, I'm afraid that's been exaggerated some--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: No. No. A signal service to the State. Yes, indeed. And not only that but-- uh--I've heard of your excellent work in leading and guiding our youth--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well--that's not work, sir--that's fun.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: No doubt. No doubt. And this fine little paper--"Boy Stuff"--with, I dare say, an *enormous* circulation in the State.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Well--yes--I was saying--the State should reward you--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Aw--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: --And it is in my power to confer a very signal honor upon you. In my official capacity, therefore, I--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Ma! Hold him!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Thanks, Governor--*yes*! Do you mind? His head--Ma'll take the tail.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: The--head?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Just get one hand against each ear there--keep his face straight up.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: What were you saying, Governor? Sorry.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: I said, sir--in my official capacity-- as an honorary gesture--I appoint you to the United States Senate!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's the matter, Dad? Is it getting you down?

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Is *what* getting me down?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Gosh, Pop--head of the Boy Rangers!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Oh, a *boy*!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: I did. What about it?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Well, Jeff put that out himself.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Himself!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: "Boy Stuff." That's the name of Jeff's magazine. He prints it.  Look--here's one--oh, it's great-- *everybody* reads it--all the kids in the State--a million of 'em. Look, Pop--let me read you a--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Peter, I'm in no mood to hear childish prattle!

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: He's the greatest *American* we got, too, Dad. Can tell what George Washington said--by heart. An' "Boy Stuff's" got the swellest stuff in it.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: What stuff?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: No, *sir*! You couldn't do better, Dad.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Than what?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: Jeff for Senator.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Emma! Will you *please*--?

turns.speaker: OTIS
turns.text: A dirty frame!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Emma!

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: I *thought* I heard... Yes?

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Uh--Jefferson Smith's residence?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Yes. Come in.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Is--uh--Jefferson Smith at home?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Certainly. Step right in.

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Well--it started with a little mimeograph sheet--and it's just grown out of all sense and reason--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Excellent! Excellent! My boy, I'm convinced our State has a great debt of gratitude to you--

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Maybe you'd like to come along and watch, Governor? Jefferson's done a wonderful job with that leg.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Why, of course.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: A pet shop?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Well, it sort of got to be--from Jeff just pullin' splinters and things--

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: I just can't, son--not the head and tail both!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Uh--could--could I help--?

turns.speaker: JIMMIE
turns.text: Gee, I wouldn't appoint an old twerp like Horace Miller--Taylor or no Taylor!

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Taylor! May I ask what *Taylor* has to do with it?

turns.speaker: JIMMIE
turns.text: Well, he's still running the show, ain't he, Dad?

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: Emma! I will not have conversations of this sort carried on by the children at dinner!

turns.speaker: JIMMIE
turns.text: That's easy. Jefferson Smith.

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: JIMMIE
turns.text: When Jeff gets through with Taylor, Pop--

turns.speaker: HUBERT
turns.text: When Jeff gets through with Taylor--  Quiet! What do you mean by breaking in here--? Get out! Get *out* of here!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Washington!

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: Yeah, for the fifth time, Senator-- Washington.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: My pigeons--I better see about my pigeons.

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: The porter's got them. They're coming.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Just a minute, I better make sure.

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: Boy! My head's like a balloon--for two whole days. I never knew there was so much American history.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Here they are--I got them. They are all right.

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: Well, that ends that crisis. This way, Senator.

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: All right, Senator--let's get these bags and the livestock together--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Look! There it is!

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: What? Who?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You should hear our Ranger Band rattle that off--if you want to *hear* something! Good evening, Miss Saunders. Good evening Mister McGann.

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: H'ya, Senator. I--I've sorta been looking for you--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You have?  Will you come in a minute, Miss Saunders.

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: Uh--Senator--I thought you and me might go out to dinner together--and grab off a few monuments.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh, I couldn't tonight. Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: He's a newspaper publisher I know-- and--

turns.speaker: MCGANN
turns.text: What makes you think he's got *anything* to do with it?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Saunders said--this whole thing was *his* idea to get graft--!

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: Where were you?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: To--to a reception--uh--for a princess-- I forget her name--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Mr. President!

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: Mr. President!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I addressed the Chair first, sir!

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: I am about to ask for a roll call on the passage of the Resolution--without further delay. The Senator can have nothing to say at this time that would not be either in bad grace or--

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: Will the Senator yield?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: For a question!

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: Has the gentleman the effrontery-- standing there convicted and in disgrace--to try to force the postponement of that bill--?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: For one week!

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: Is he fully aware that this bill has been months in both Houses--delayed and delayed--millions will be without food and shelter until its passage-- public works to relieve unemployment will be at a standstill--government agencies will be forced to suspend-- ?

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: Will the Senator yield for a question?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I yield.

turns.speaker: SENATOR
turns.text: In view of the gentleman's touching concern for the Senators, would he permit a motion to recess until the morning--at which time he could continue to educate this august body with his profound babblings?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well, it isn't much, but if you insist, here's this week's.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: "Boy Stuff." Why, printer's ink runs in your veins, Jeff. You're just like your father.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Even to the hat. Same old dreamer, too. One look at you and I can see him, back of his old roll top desk, hat and all, getting out his paper. Always kept his hat on his head so as to be ready to do battle. Clayton Smith, editor and publisher, and champion of lost causes.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yeah, Dad always used to say the only causes worth fighting for were lost causes.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: You don't have to tell me Jeff. We were a team, the two of us, a struggling editor and a struggling lawyer. The twin champions of lost causes, they used to call us.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Ma's told me about it a thousand times.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: His last fight was his best, Jeff. He and his little four-page paper against that mining syndicate and all to defend the right of one small miner who stuck to his claim. You know, they tried everything, bribery, intimidation, then--well--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, Ma found him slumped over his desk that morning...

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Shot in the back. I was there. I can see him at that old roll top desk, still with his hat on... still with his hat on...

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I know. I suppose, Mr. Paine, when a fellow bucks up against a big organization like that, one man by himself can't get very far, can he?

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I mean, sir--if I'm going to stay in the Senate--I ought to know what I'm doing--at least, I ought to try to study the Bills that are coming up--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: The *Bills*? Jeff--let me advise you-- as your father would--politics is a business--sometimes a cruel business. In your time here, you couldn't even start on those Bills. They're put together by legal minds--after a long study. Why, after twenty years, I can't understand half of them myself. No, really, Jeff--in your own interests--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well, then--I--I don't feel I can stay, sir.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Jeff, look--didn't you say something to the papers about wanting to create a National Boys' camp? Were you in earnest about that?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, I was--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Well, why not do it? There's a job for you. Get a Bill started to accomplish it--present it to Congress-- it would be a great experience--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Senator Paine, if I could do just that one thing while I'm here, I-- I'd feel that I--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: What's to stop you? Saunders will help you with it--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I will, sir! I will!  I--I don't know how to thank you. I knew, if any man could help me--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Nonsense, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Thank you, sir. Thank you for your time.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Here--where are you running off to?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well, I'm sort of anxious to get back to the office--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I'm sorry! Gee! I hope--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: That's all right, my boy--don't bother--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Gosh!  Well--looks good as new. If there *is* any damage, I'll--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Good as new! It's quite all right--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well--goodnight.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Goodnight, Jeff.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Goodnight, Miss Paine.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: --I may not know much about a lot of things, sir--but I know that Willet Creek country like a book--and--and I tell you, Senator Paine--there's something *wrong* about this dam-- why, there isn't a foot of water in that creek--it's dry four months out of the--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Jeff--listen--this was all taken up in the State Legislature and approved-- they're going to divert waters from up above--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: But--there are a hundred other places in the state that *need* the water. Besides--I talked to Kenneth Allen, who owns some of that land--and he didn't say anything about a dam. No-- I'm sure, sir--there's something wrong--and I--I won't vote on this thing until I get a lot of questions answered--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Jeff! You're trying to understand in a moment everything about a project that took two years to set up--the reasons--the benefits--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes--the *benefits*! What's a man called Taylor got to do with this?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Y-yes.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Mr. President--gentlemen--I--I have risen to a painful duty--to say that, out of evidence that has come to my attention, I consider Senator Smith unworthy to address this body!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yield *how*, sir?

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Will he yield for a question?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Ah, now, that's better.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Will he *yield*?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: For a *question*.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Does my colleague's piece concern Section Forty of the bill--a dam on Willet Creek?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: It does!

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Every *aspect* of this matter--the gentleman's attack on that section-- everything--was dealt with in the committee hearing--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Mr. President--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: I wish to ask the gentleman--has he one shred of evidence to add now to the defense he did not give--and *could* not give at that same hearing?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I have no defense against forged papers and--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: The committee ruled otherwise! The gentleman stands guilty as charged. And I believe I speak for all the members when I say that no one cares to hear what a man of his condemned character has to say about *any* section of *any* legislation before this house!

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Will the Senator--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I will not yield, sir! This same man-- Mister Taylor--came here to offer me a place in this Senate for twenty years, if I would vote for a dam that he knew and *I* knew was a *fraud*! But if I opened my mouth against it, he promised to break me in two! And I stood here one day and tried--I *started* to open my mouth-- and it all came to pass. The long, powerful arm of Mister James Taylor reached right into this sacred chamber and took me by the scruff of the neck--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Mr. President! A point of order!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Mr. President--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Mr. President--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: He has imputed to me conduct unworthy a Senator--and I demand he be made to yield the floor--!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Mr. President--I did not say that Senator Paine was one of those Congressmen I saw. If the chair please, I will deny that Senator Paine *saw* Taylor or even knows him--

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: I *did* see Taylor! And I was in that room!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, sir, I yield for a question.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: The gentleman has said repeatedly that he is speaking to the people of his State. He has been waiting, as he so fancifully puts it, for them to come marching here in droves. Would the gentleman be interested in knowing what those people have to say?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, sir, you bet I would.

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: Mr. President, have I permission to bring into this Chamber evidence of the response from my State?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Please, sir!--come with me!

turns.speaker: PAINE
turns.text: No, Jeff--please--!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I say it's *your* parade, sir! You've *got* to come!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Good evening, sir. I was just making some--  Governor Hopper!

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Well--I'll go to Halifax!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh, now--

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Jefferson--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, Ma?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Excuse me for interrupting, Governor, but--  --that plaster's gonna harden any second, son.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Gosh! You see sir--I was fixing some plaster for a cast on Amos' leg-- he's always chewing 'em off. I'll only be a minute--if you'll excuse me, sir--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Jerry! Blackie! Queenie! Let's have it quiet, fellows!

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Now, now, now!  It's all right, Governor.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Now, now, now--that isn't going to get you any place. Get a firm grip, Ma!

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Satan's in this little fella tonight!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Sorry about this, Governor. But it won't take a minute. You were saying something in the other room, sir--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Now, Amos, now--  What?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Hello, Jefferson.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Hello, Ma.  Clarissa, Ma. She'll be stayin' a while--

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Fine--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: And Senator Paine too, Ma--we'd like to have him--

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Certainly would, Joseph.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: How's Amos, Ma?

turns.speaker: MA
turns.text: Just fine.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: We'd better see.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Well. I hear you've been right on your toes since you got here. Pitching right in. Lots of people took you for dumb--but they're wrong. You're smart. In fact, *I* think you're smart enough to understand a situation when it's explained to you--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Like what, Mr. Taylor?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Well now--just to take an example-- putting up a dam--on Willet Creek. As I look at it--that dam's going to do the people of our state a lot of good--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, so I was told, Mr. Taylor, but--

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: But you have some objections here and there. And maybe right, for all I know. But the point is--there's no sense stopping the whole works now-- specially after some men have worked hard for a long time to put this through--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: What is your interest in this, Mr. Taylor?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Mine? Why--naturally--whatever benefits the state is mighty important to me--owning a lot of its industry-- newspapers and other odds and ends. And if I thought you had the welfare of the state at heart, like myself-- for instance, if you were to turn around and help a project like this along instead of standing in the way-- why, I'd say you were a man to watch. For a fellow your age, you'd be in a spot to make a great start in life. If you liked business--you could pick any job in the state and go right to the top. Or politics. If you like being a Senator. No reason why you couldn't come back to that Senate for the rest of your life.

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Can't you?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You mean--you tell these men--and Senator Paine what to do?

turns.speaker: TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes! I've told Senator Paine for twenty years--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You're a liar!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Office of--Senator Smith?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: *No*!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: The man downstairs said number--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: J-Jefferson Smith.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Is--is something the matter?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Oh, no--no!  My dear *Senator*--it may be customary out on the prairie to take French leave of people and not be heard of again for five hours--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Gee--I'm sorry about that, Miss--you *are* Miss Saunders, aren't you?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Yes, I'm Saunders--and this is Mr. Moore--a member of the press. Meet the *Senator*, Mr. Moore.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Pleased to meet you, sir.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Gee, I'm sorry. You see, it wasn't until I was fairly well along in the bus that I realized--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Did you say--bus?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: One of those sightseers--you know. You see, I--gosh, I've never been called absent-minded or... but there it was all of a sudden--looking right at me through one of the station doors--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: There *what* was?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: The Dome--the Capitol Dome--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: --big as life--sparkling away there under the sun. I--I started walking toward it--and there was a bus outside-- and--well--I--I just naturally got aboard--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Most natural thing in the world!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I don't believe I've been so thrilled in my--oh, and that Lincoln Memorial! Gee! There he is--Mr. Lincoln--looking right at you as you come up the steps-- sitting there like he was waiting for someone to come along--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Well--he's got nothing on me.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Now, if you're ready, Senator, we can start for the hotel. I'll *see* that you get there.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes--I think maybe you'd better.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Whose statue is that?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I wouldn't know in the *day time*.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: The Capitol Dome! Lighted up!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: You--uh--you better relax, Senator. You'll be plumb wore out.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Tell me, Miss Saunders--what time does the Senate--uh--what do they call it?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Convene?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Convene--that's it--yes. I got to pick up some of those parliamentary words. I imagine a fellow can get pretty lost in the Senate without 'em--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: With or without 'em.  Twelve--noon. The Senate convenes at twelve o'clock.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Gosh--that'll be something! You know what I better do in the morning?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No. What had you better--?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Go out to Mount Vernon. It'd be a sort of fine thing to do--see Washington's home just before walking into the Senate for the first time-- don't you think?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Oh--a wonderful thing--yes. Get you right in the mood--yes--yes.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: No, gee--I couldn't stay here--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: You *couldn't*?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I mean--gosh--I wouldn't be comfortable in a--I--I haven't got clothes and things like that--and--I couldn't keep pigeons *there*--No--I-- I just--just wouldn't be--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Go ahead--punch.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Punch?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I had a lot to do with that little press conference last night--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well, then, I--I *thank* you, Miss Saunders! Nothing better could have happened--. Yes *sir*, Miss Saunders, we're going right ahead with it!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: We're going right ahead with--*what*?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Why, the Bill--the Bill--to make a National Boys' Camp...

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: One moment, Senator. Do I understand you're going to present a *Bill*?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Sure! A Bill. Senator Paine and I decided it was the one way in the world I could make myself--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Pardon me. Senator Paine decided this *with* you?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes. Sure. It was his idea. *I* should have been the one to think of it--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: My dear Senator, have you the faintest idea of what it takes to get a Bill passed?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I know--but you--you're going to help.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: If I were *triplets*, I couldn't--. Look, Senator--let me give you a rough idea. A member has a Bill in mind--like you--a camp. Right?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Fine. Now, what does he do? He's got to sit down first and write it up. The where, when, why, how--and everything else. That takes time--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh, but this one is so simple.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I see. *This* one is so simple--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: And with your help--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Oh, yes. And *I'm* helping. Simple-- and I'm helping. So we knock this off in record-breaking time of--let's say three or four days--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh, just a day--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: A *day*!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Tonight.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Tonight.  Look--uh--I don't want to seem to be complaining, Senator--but in all civilized countries, there's an institution called *dinner*--!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh--dinner. Yes. Well, I'm hungry, too. I thought--maybe--we could have something brought in--you know, like big executives who eat off trays. You see, we've got to light into this and get it going--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Uh-huh. Well, dinner comes in on trays. We're executives. And we light into this. It is dawn. Your Bill is ready. You go over there and introduce it--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: You get to your feet in the Senate and present it. Then you take the Bill and put it in a little box-- like a letter box--on the side of the rostrum. Just hold it between thumb and forefinger and drop it in. Clerks read it and refer it to the right committee--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Committee, huh?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Committee.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: That's how Congress--or any large body--is run. All work has to be done by committee.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Look--committees--small groups of Senators--have to sift a Bill down-- look into it--study it--and report to the whole Senate. You can't take a Bill no one knows anything about and discuss it among ninety-six men. Where would you get?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, I see that.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Good. Where are we?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Some committee's got it.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Yes. They give it to a *sub*- committee, where they really give it a going over--hold hearings--call in people and ask questions--then report back to the bigger committee--where it's considered some more, changed, amended, or whatever. Days are going by, Senator. Days--weeks. Finally, they think it's quite a Bill. It goes over to the House of Representatives for debate and a vote. *But* it's got to wait its turn on the calendar--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Calendar?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: That's the order of business. Your Bill has to stand *way* back there in line unless the Steering Committee decides it is important enough to be--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: The Steering Committee.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Do you really think we're getting anywhere.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes. Sure. What's a Steering Committee?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: A committee of the majority party leaders. They decide when a Bill is important enough to be moved up toward the head of the list--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: *This* is.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Pardon me--*this* is. Where are we now?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: We're over in the House.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Yes. House. More amendments--more changes--and the Bill goes back to the Senate--and *waits its turn on the calendar again*. The Senate doesn't like what the house did to the Bill. They make more changes. The House doesn't like *those* changes. Stymie. So they appoint men from each house to go into a huddle called a conference and battle it out. Besides that, all the lobbyists interested give cocktail parties for and against--government departments get in their two cents' worth--cabinet members--budget bureaus--embassies. Finally, if the Bill is alive after all this vivisection, it comes to a vote. Yes, sir--the big day finally arrives. And--nine times out of ten, they vote it down.  Are you catching on, Senator?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes. Shall we start on it right now-- or order dinner first?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Pardon?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I said--shall we get started *now* or--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Yes--sure. Why not?  You don't mind if I take the time to get a pencil?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: No! Go right ahead, Miss Saunders.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Thanks very much.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: And a *lot* of paper!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: --that's the main idea, Miss Saunders. The United States Government isn't going to buy or build this camp-- just lend us the money. You've made a note of that, huh?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Yes, Senator--*twice*.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Uh--have you?  Did you ever have so much to say about something--you couldn't say it?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Try sitting down.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I did--and--and I got right up.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Now, let's get down to particulars. How big is this thing? Where is it to be? How many boys will it take care of? If they're going to buy it-- how do they make their contributions? Your Bill has to have all that in it--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: And something else, too, Miss Saunders-- the spirit of it--the idea--the--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: On paper?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I want to make that come to life-- yes, and lighted up like that, too-- for every boy in the land. Boys forget what their country means--just reading "land of the free" in history books. And they get to be men--and forget even more. Liberty is too precious to get buried in books, Miss Saunders. Men ought to hold it up in front of them--every day of their lives and say: "I am free--to think--to speak. My ancestors couldn't. I can. My children will."

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well--gosh--that--that isn't "particulars," is it?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: But you've just taken care of the spirit all right.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well, anyway, it's *something* like that--  And it *is* important. That--that Steering Committee has *got* to see it that way. And I'm sure Senator Paine will do all he can--  He's a fine man, Miss Saunders, isn't he? He knew my father, you know.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: He did?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: We need a lot like him--his kind of character--ideals.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Uh--getting back to this, Senator--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes, yes--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Now, this camp is going to be out in your state, of course--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: About two hundred of the most beautiful acres that ever were! Mountains, prairie land, trees, streams! A paradise for boys who live in stuffy cities--  You don't know that country out there, do you, Miss Saunders?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I've been over every foot of it. You couldn't have any idea. You'd have to see for yourself--  --the prairies--the wind leaning on the tall grass--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You mean--here?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Baltimore. Pure city-dweller.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: But you've had beautiful country all around you. You've just had to life up your eyes!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: City-dwellers never do that--for fear of what might drop *in* 'em.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Have you always had to--work?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Since sixteen or so.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I take it your--your parents couldn't-- uh--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No, they couldn't. Father was a doctor. The kind who placed ethics above collections. That speaks well for Father but it always left us kind of--  Could we get on with this, Senator?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: It hasn't been easy, has it?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No complaints.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: But--I mean--for a woman--And--you've done awfully well--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Have I?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I never met anyone more--more intelligent--or capable. I--I don't know where I'd be on this bill of mine without your help--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I don't see where we are *with* it.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: No! Gosh! I better get moving here, Miss Saunders--  Everybody else calls you just plain "Saunders." Why can't I?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Go right ahead.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Saunders. That's better.  Good morning, Saunders. Hello, Saunders. How's the bill coming, Saunders--?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Terrible, thank you.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah. Well, anyway, we've got "Saunders" settled. Maybe that was my trouble all along.  YEs, *sir*. I'm all ready to go now--  What's your *first* name?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well--nobody calls you anything but Saunders.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I also answer to whistles.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You--you've *got* a first name, haven't you?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Look--I think we ought to skip it.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: All right. Sure. Just curious. The picture popped into my mind all of a sudden of a pump without a handle-- or something--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Well, if it's all the same to you--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I know. It's--Violet.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: It *is* not!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Abigail.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Letitia.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Lena.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No! Stop it!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I've got more. You better tell me.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: You win. It's--Clarissa.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Clarissa. Oh. Uh-huh.  Well, Saunders--let's go--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Now, *Susan*--that's really a *pretty* name--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Susan! Susan Paine--that's beautiful--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: And a beautiful woman, too--don't you think?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yes. The most beautiful I think I ever--gee--  Say--we're *never* going to finish this thing! Now, here we go, Saunders. I'm going to talk faster'n you can write--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Uh--Willet Creek. It's just a little stream--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: In Terry Canyon?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You--don't know it, do you?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You couldn't. You've never been out there, you said.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No, I haven't. I guess I thought the name was familiar.  By the way, you discussed with Senator Paine where the camp was to be situated and everything?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well--no. I didn't. Why?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Nothing. I just wondered. No *reason* to take it up with him.  "--about a quarter of a mile on either side of Willet Creek--"

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yeah. This land to be bought by contributions from the boys. You have that. Money to be--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: What do they--? Who are all those--?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: One of the plagues on members of Congress--office-seekers, cranks, people with pet bills. Get my son into West Point--or *outta* West Point. I've got a scheme to put people to work. How do I get rid of cockroaches? Some woman's composed a hymn to replace the Star Spangled Banner. Want to hear it?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: No--not today! Boy, I feel like a house afire! Saunders--how did I do?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I--I don't know how I got it out. My heart was right up here all the time--  I wonder what Senator Paine thought of it?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Must have been tickled pink.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Gee--I hope so. What's all this?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Contributions from boys who read about your camp.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Already? All these letters?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Oh, those are only local. Wait'll they start pouring in from all over the country.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Do you mean all--look--look we'd better open them up--see what they say here--look at the money--what does it say--"Dear Senator Smith, I would like to come to your boy's camp and I shine shoes at the station and here's nine cents." Oh, isn't that wonderful. Look and he signs it. "Yours truly, Stinky Moore." Isn't that marvelous?  Say--have I got some paper here?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Second drawer.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Good! I'm going to be pretty busy tonight--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Not another bill?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: No! Letters. I've got to write to the Rangers and Ma--and--I'm bustin' with news! Why, I've introduced a bill! Me--Jeff Smith. I got up and talked in the Senate!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Do you want to dictate them?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: The letters? Gosh--no. I couldn't talk letters. I've gotta scratch 'em out. And say--I'm going to tell Ma all about you. If I tell it right-- the first thing you know you're going to get the best jar of preserves you ever tasted.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh--*Saunders*!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I--I--gee whiz--I didn't thank you!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Don't mention it--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I mean it. I--without you, I could't've--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Yes--right here. Just a second--  Miss Paine.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: *Who*! Miss--! Is that--? Why didn't you--? Holy smoke;  H-hello... Yes, Miss Paine... How-- how are you, Miss Paine...? What?... Escort *you* Gee--I mean--*sure*-- *yes*! I'd be--. Reception for a *princess*! Gosh!... Thanks, Miss Paine. Yes. I--I'll be there! Goodbye, Miss Paine.  Did you hear that?--Escort Susan Paine--reception for a princess! Imagine her calling me--asking *me*-- !

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Get your hat, Senator. We've got a lot to do between now and tomorrow--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Wow!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I know. Don't tell me. It was a wonderful party. Your suit went over big. And she looked beautiful, and she gave her hand when you left her-- and said--"Thank you, Mr. Smith." Oh, but it was the way she *said* it. You like to fell through the floor--Horseradish!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Saunders--!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: And you're writing Ma all about it. And your pigeons will carry the message of love. And the first thing you know--Susan Paine'll get the best jar of preserves she ever tasted!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Are you drunk?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Saunders--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well gee--how--how've you been, Saunders? I--I haven't seen you in-- . I suppose--now that you're married--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I'm not.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: No. That night--I--well, *you* know-- I was pretty--. No--Diz is a--a sort of brother, that's all--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: That's funny. I thought all along--  Gee--I--I'm glad to see you. I *thought* of you--I mean--I wanted to talk to someone and--well--  --Mr. Lincoln hasn't much to say--  Saunders--I'm not fit to sit up in the Senate--haven't you heard?--I robbed boys of their pennies and dimes!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I--I don't know. I--I'm afraid they've got me licked.

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: It might save some of the pieces, Jeff. It would leave a doubt about the whole thing--about you. Might blow over, this way.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yeah. I see. Well--that's about the only thing to do. Don't you think?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Well, I guess it's a chance.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yeah. I guess--sometimes--Senator Paine must be right. Sometimes you-- you got to compromise a little--  And if you say so too, Saunders--if *you* think that's the thing to do--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I *don't* think that's the thing to do! No! I think what you ought to do is--*fight*!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Wait--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: What you *have* to do is fight!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: But--I've done everything I--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: I don't care *what* you've done! Don't quit. Don't grab a measly chance like this to save a few pieces--other men could--but not you. As long as you lived, you'd remember you ran out and threw this country of yours to the jackals--!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh--Saunders--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Jeff--listen--remember the day you got here?--what you said about Mr. Lincoln?--that he was sitting up there--watching--waiting for someone to come along? Well--that was *you*. Someone with a little plain, decent, uncompromising *rightness*--to root out the Taylors--yeah, and really light up that dome for once. This country could use some of that--so could the whole drunken, cockeyed world right now--a *lot* of it! And when the right man comes along--no matter *what* the odds--he can't *ever* quit! A little fellow called David walked out with only a sling- shot--but he had the *truth* on his side--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Saunders--if there was *any* way--

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: We'll *find* one! Only throw compromise out of the window--stick to Jeff Smith, the man who first came to this town--get up and *fight*-- and we'll find *some* way. I don't know where we'll wind up--but the flag'll be flying--!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Yay!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Hurray!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Where do we go from here?

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: To a hard night's work, son. Come on!

turns.speaker: SAUNDERS
turns.text: Jeff--wait--they want you to speak!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Not *me*! Joseph Paine is the man they ought to be listening to! Come on!

turns.speaker: VOICES
turns.text: Tell us about yourself, Senator! Hear you got a Boy's Club back home! Any ideas? Going to make things hum in the Senate, huh?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Hold on, fellows--I'm not used to more then one question at a time--

turns.speaker: VOICES
turns.text: Ah! That's more like it! What?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well--for a couple of years now--I-- I've thought it would be a wonderful thing to have a National Boys' Camp out in our State--

turns.speaker: VOICES
turns.text: A camp! Well!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: You see--if we could take the poor kids off the streets--out of cities-- a few months in the summer--learn something about Nature and American ideals--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: *Gentlemen*! Gentlemen are supposed to believe in something decent. Instead of twisting facts and making a joke of everything--why don't you tell the people the *truth* for a change?

turns.speaker: VOICES
turns.text: The truth! Well, the man wants the truth! "What *is* truth?" asked so-and-so, and turned away!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: That's what I said--the *truth*!

turns.speaker: VOICES
turns.text: Whoa! Hold it! Pipe down! Come on, now--that's enough of that.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: If you thought as much of being honest-- as you do of being smart--!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Just for the fun of it.--You see the one that makes it back home in the fastest time, I am going to enter in the nationals.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Wonderful!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well, we *must* see a lot of you, Senator. Come, Father.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: How--how do you do, Miss Paine?  I--I apologize for looking like this-- I--I have to be going now--

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: How are the pigeons?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Fine--they're fine.  Oh, Miss Paine, I--I want to apologize-- what the papers said I said about you--that wasn't true. I--I would never say a thing like that.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Did you hear, Father? He didn't mean it when he said I was beautiful.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh--you are!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Then you *did* say it.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: No--I mean--yes--that is--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Well, goodbye, sir--and thank you again.  Well--it--it was nice seeing you, Miss Paine--

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Goodnight, Senator--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I--I'm awfully glad to be--that is, it was nice of you to--  Uh--how's your father?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Splendid.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Uh--that's good. And--uh--you?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm splendid, too.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: That's--that's splendid.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And how's your bill, Senator?

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Oh, the bill. Oh--splendid--I mean--  I--I just can't seem to talk in this suit.  I'll tell you a secret. It's brand new.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well! You don't say!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: It's just as well to tell you--because if we're going to get off on the right foot--I mean--in case I act sort of strange--it's the suit.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well--I--

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: Funnier things have happened. Ma says when Pa was courting her, he acted strange for months. Didn't make sense--or anything. And one day, on a hunch, Ma said: "Clayton, so help me, you talk like a man whose collar is too tight to bear." "Not the collar, Mary," he said, "my shoes." "Well, for land's sake," Ma said, "Take the pesky things off!" Which Pa did, an' they were engaged within a week.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You're not going to take your *suit* off!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: No! No! Gosh. See, there you are! I'm not making sense!

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I don't understand, sir! I don't know what the gentleman--

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: The Senator has no voice in this chamber until the oath of office has been administered!

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: "I do solemnly swear--that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States--against all enemies, foreign and domestic--that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same--that I take this obligation freely--without and mental reservation and purpose of evasion-- and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which I am about to enter. So help me God."

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: "So help me God."

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: Senator, you can talk all you want to, now.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT
turns.text: The chair recognizes the rather strong- lunged junior Senator, Mr. Smith.

turns.speaker: JEFFERSON
turns.text: I--I'm sorry, sir. I--I have a bill--
